titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Grimes Family Films and Other Materials AIA.040
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Bonnie Gordon

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-04-23T14:12-0400

change.item: Revised by Rachel Searcy to incorporate additional descriptive information

did.unittitle: Grimes Family Films and Other Materials

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.physloc: Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.
did.abstract: The Grimes Family is an Irish American family based in the greater New York City area perhaps best known for their ownership of the Irish Echo newspaper from 1955 until 2011. Through its domestic and international social, political, sporting, and entertainment coverage, the Irish Echo served as a channel of communication and source of documentation for the Irish American community. This collection consists of home movies, photographs, publications, ephemera, and other materials created and collected by members of the Grimes Family, including Paddy, John, and Claire. The majority of the collection is comprised of some of the Grimes’ home movies, documenting family life as well as various Irish American social functions in the greater New York City area during the 1950s. Some of the more prominent subjects of these films include sporting events, St. Patrick’s Day parades, and United Irish Counties Association Feiseanna at Fordham University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Archives of Irish American United Irish Counties Association Collection (AIA 056)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Grimes Family Films and Other Materials; AIA 040; box number; folder number; Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Grimes Family is an Irish American family based in the greater New York City area perhaps best known for their ownership of the Irish Echo newspaper from 1955 until 2011. Patrick J. (Paddy) Grimes, a native of Co. Offaly, purchased the newspaper in 1955 in an attempt to promote the family’s travel agency, Grimes Travel Agency. Through its domestic and international social, political, sporting, and entertainment coverage, the Irish Echo served as a channel of communication and source of documentation for the Irish American community. For example, the paper produced brochures and journals for the various county societies and other social organizations in the 1950s and 1960s. Following Paddy’s death in 1978, his son John became the paper’s editor and publisher until his death in 1987, after which his wife Claire assumed the roles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of home movies, photographs, publications, ephemera, and other materials created and collected by members of the Grimes Family, including Paddy, John, and Claire. The majority of the collection is comprised of some of the Grimes’ home movies, documenting family life as well as various Irish American social functions in the greater New York City area during the 1950s. Some of the more prominent subjects of these films include sporting events, St. Patrick’s Day parades, and United Irish Counties Association Feiseanna at Fordham University.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Prcoedures
phystech.p: Researchers interested in using audiovisual materials in this collection (films, cassette tapes, VHS tapes, et cetera) must use a digitized copy, which we refer to as an access copy. Researchers may view an item’s original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that already have already been digitized are noted in the collection’s finding aid and can be requested in our reading room; materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. These requests are free of charge and can be made in anticipation of your visit. The process typically takes four to six weeks. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A librarian will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The Tamiment Library does not have information about who owns copyright to this collection. The films in this collection are expected to enter the public domain in 2057. The remainder of the collection is expected to enter into the public domain beginning in 2016. The Tamiment Library is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from this collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Films were donated by Claire Grimes in the late 1990s. The accession number associated with this gift is 1997.041. The remainder of the collection was donated by Claire Grimes several years later.
